Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: StressTyp2: A Database for Word Accentual Patterns in the World's Languages

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Words and phrases in many languages exhibit distinct rhythmic patterns. These rhythmic patterns are often referred to as "stress patterns" or "accent patterns." Over the past several decades, both field linguists and theoretical linguists have endeavored to understand the nature of these patterns in individual languages and the range of variation that exists across languages. The goal of this project is the construction and dissemination of a typological database, to be called StressTyp2 (ST2), which documents and organizes these patterns in the world's languages.

The PIs have three specific tasks. First, they will merge the information in existing databases of stress and accent patterns. Second, they will improve, verify and enrich the dataset in a variety of ways and develop a web-based interface that makes the information in ST2 available to researchers and citizens around the world, and which meets or exceeds professional and scientific standards. The third goal of this project is to adopt (and, where necessary, establish) best practices for the collection, organization, dissemination and presentation of typological data pertaining to sound patterns in natural language.

There are many issues in constructing cross-linguistic data resources. The PIs will focus on the complex logical structure involved in a relational database which tracks dozens of linguistic properties, developing standards for assessing the accuracy or confidence of linguistic descriptions of lesser studied languages, and statistical sampling techniques for evaluating how representative the information in ST2 is of the world's languages and particular language families.

This research will fund two public workshops on word accent systems with domestic and international experts, which will both educate and inspire attendees, which will include professors, graduate students and undergraduate students. Additionally, undergraduate and graduate students will receive significant amounts of training as research assistants in the collection, verification, dissemination and analysis of linguistic data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Words and phrases in many languages exhibit distinct rhythmicpatterns. These rhythmic patterns are often referred to as "stress" or"accent" patterns. Over the past several decades, both field linguistsand theoretical linguists have endeavored to understand the nature ofthese patterns in individual languages and the range of variation thatexists across languages.
This project created and disseminated a typological database calledStressTyp2 (ST2) which documents and organizes these patterns in theworld's languages according to linguistic variables and computationalmodels. ST2 is available online at [http://st2.ullet.net]. The onlineversion of ST2 is continually updated as information about newlanguages is added, and as the understanding about previouslydocumented languages improves. Static versions of ST2 are archivedwith the Linguistic Data Consortium at the University of Pennsylvaniaso that research studies based on the contents of ST2 can bereplicated and verified.
The project's intellectual merit revolves around several criticalissues involved in organizing and disseminating information aboutnatural languages. It is an interesting problem how to represent thecomplex logical structure present in dozens of linguistic variables ina relational database, and to make them accessible to people withdifferent amounts of knowledge. This projects coded information aboutword stress/accent systems in several different schemes, including Englishprose, theoretical linguistic terms, and computationally explicitrepresentations, which maximizes both the utility and longevity of theinformation.
ST2 makes it easier for students, scholars and the general public tolearn about the nature of stress and accent in the world'slanguages. This helps people understand the range of variation thatexists cross-linguistically. An additional broader impact of theresearch is that the ST2 database serves as a model for how theinformation in complex linguistic subsystems can be organized andpresented to a worldwide audience.
In addition to journal articles and conference papers produced as aconsequence of this research, three monographs have been edited, two of which are now published,with chapters by nationally and internationally recognized scholars onstress and accent containing new emprical and theoretical findings.Additionally, undergraduate and graduate students received significantamounts of training as research assistants in the collection,verification, dissemination and analysis of one of the most preciousgifts to humanity, natural language.
